definition[0]: to make a good combination with someone or something else
example[0]: John and Bob complemented each other well.
example[1]: The dark red walls complement the red leather chairs.
explanation[0]: In everyday English, people usually say that something goes well with another thing, or they go well together, rather than say they complement each other:
example[2]: White wine goes well with fish.
definition[1]: someone or something that emphasizes the good qualities of another person or thing
example[3]: This wine would be a nice complement to grilled dishes.
definition[2]: the number or quantity needed to make a group complete
example[4]: Each new cell will carry its full complement of chromosomes.
definition[3]: a word or phrase that follows a verb and describes the subject of the verb. In ‘John is cold’ and ‘John became chairman’, ‘cold’ and ‘chairman’ are complements.
